customer_addr:

Boston, MA 02121

citations.narrative:
Enclosures housing ring-tailed lemurs are constructed with a coated concrete floor. There are areas of the floor surface
that has lifted, cracked, or is missing entirely. In one pen, there is an area of approximately 4” x 4” where the floor coating
has lifted off the underlying concrete. The material is broken at the top, exposing a lip of broken material and a pocket
under the floor surface approximately 1” deep. In another pen, there is an area of approximately 6” x 10” where the
flooring material is missing, exposing the underlying surface. The visible concrete is stained and dark in color beneath the
disrupted coating.
In one holding enclosure for colobus monkeys, there is an area on the concrete floor where the material is cracked and
lifted from the underlying material over an area of approximately 3” x 12” inches. There are visible gaps in the surface and
some pieces of the concrete material appear loose.
Flooring material in poor repair creates areas that are difficult to clean and sanitize and loose flooring material may be
hazardous to the animals.
To be corrected be ensuring that primary enclosures used to house nonhuman primates are maintained in good repair.
Correct by 9/16/2023.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 7th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.80(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Enclosures housing ring-tailed lemurs are constructed with a coated concrete floor. There are areas of the floor surface 
that has lifted, cracked, or is missing entirely. In one pen, there is an area of approximately 4” x 4” where the floor coating 
has lifted off the underlying concrete. The material is broken at the top, exposing a lip of broken material and a pocket 
under the floor surface approximately 1” deep. In another pen, there is an area of approximately 6” x 10” where the 
flooring material is missing, exposing the underlying surface. The visible concrete is stained and dark in color beneath the 
disrupted coating.  
 
In one holding enclosure for colobus monkeys, there is an area on the concrete floor where the material is cracked and 
lifted from the underlying material over an area of approximately 3” x 12” inches. There are visible gaps in the surface and 
some pieces of the concrete material appear loose. 
 
Flooring material in poor repair creates areas that are difficult to clean and sanitize and loose flooring material may be 
hazardous to the animals.  
 
To be corrected be ensuring that primary enclosures used to house nonhuman primates are maintained in good repair. 
Correct by 9/16/2023. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 7th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

n
